creditline: Museum purchase, gift of Mrs. Walter L. Weil, by exchange

texts.textentryhtml:
Olmec Stone-carving from the Era of La Venta

Concurrent with the shift of Olmec political power from San Lorenzo, Veracruz, to La Venta, Tabasco, around 1000 B.C., widely distributed Olmec-style ceramics fade from the archaeological record, to be replaced by fine, small-scale carvings in stone, especially blue-green jadeite and serpentine. Incised jewelry, so-called “spoons,” masklike faces, and complexly modeled animal, human, and supernatural figures, all of Middle Formative date (1000–500 B.C.) and carved in Olmec style, have been discovered throughout most of Mesoamerica, from Costa Rica to the central Mexican Highlands to the southwest Mexican coast in the present-day state of Guerrero.
texts.remarks: February 2015 AAA Reinstallation WC5 Formative Mesoamerica. Group chat for 6 objects: y1987-25, 2004-21, y1990-52, y1987-43 a, 1995-188, and 2012-46; August 2015 AAA Reinstallation WC5. Group chat for six objects: L.1974.52, 2004-21, y1990-52, y1987-43a, 2015-6684, 2012-46

texts.textentryhtml: These seventeen human legs and four pebble shaped pieces of jadeite once comprised quite curious necklace.  When strung together the legs each would have faced forward, reminding the mind of a modern viewer, perhaps, of a chorus line.  The symbolic value of the row of legs is unknown.  Although relatively rare, other naturalistically rendered body parts are attested from Middle Formative Mesoamerica, which may be a part of a larger complex of symbolic associations.  The legs are similar in basic form, with flat, schematic feet, bulbous knees, and fleshy calves.  Each varies slightly in size, shape, and color.  Their original arrangement in the necklace is not known; they may have place the longer legs at the center of the necklace as displayed today, or they may have been organized to produce contrast in size and/or color from one leg to the next.  The jadeite of the set ranges in color from a light, whitish green to a deep, forest green.  Although jadeite is often considered a green stone, in its pure state it is white.  The green coloration is produced through interaction with other minerals, wherein iron is substituted in the chemical composition of the jadeite, imbuing it with green coloration.  Although the only verified source of jadeite in Mesoamerica is in southern Guatemela, it has long been thought that another source exists in Guerrero, Mexico, the same region where this neckalce was found.

Miguel Covarrubias (1904-1957), Mexico City [1]; likely before 1952, passed to his wife, Rosa Rolanda (1895-1970), Mexico City [2]; 1970, bequeathed to Nieves Orozco Field and Frederick Vanderbilt Field (1905-2000), Minneapolis, MN [3]; 1987, partial sale to the Princeton University Art Museum and partial gift of Hope Gerson (Mrs. Walter L.) Weil (1900-1986), Westchester, NY.

Notes:
[1] According to Michael D. Coe, “The Olmec Notebooks of Miguel Covarrubias,” Mesoweb Publications (2012), p. 28, a hand drawn illustration of one of 17 jade legs appears in a sketchbook kept by Miguel Covarrubias.
[2] Miguel Covarrubias and Rosa Rolanda separated in 1952, so she likely had this in her possession before parting ways. After Covarrubias’ death in 1957, his possessions were divided between his brother Luis Covarrubias, his mistress Rocío Sagaón, and his friend and fellow Olmec scholar William Spratling.
[3] Rosa Rolanda and Nieves Orozco Field, both former dancers, became friends while living in Mexico City with their husbands, both interested in pre-Columbian art.
